byline: Marco Rubio's campaign team in South Carolina operated out of a staffer's garage
description: plotting strategy for the first-in-the-South primary from freshly painted yard sale furniture and tiny classroom desks.\nThe shoestring budget setup was a point of pride for the Republican presidential candidate's team. Now
title: with Rubio enjoying a burst of momentum as the early voting contests edge closer
url: the Florida senator's campaign is moving beyond its lean and mean roots.\nOn Wednesday
topics: Rubio's South Carolina team officially moved out of the garage and into a proper campaign headquarters \u00e2\u0080\u0094 though they brought some of the yard sale furniture along with them.\n\"This election could very well be decided in this state
people: \" Rubio told the crowd gathered at the office in Columbia
org: South Carolina's capital.\nRubio's team also opened offices in Nevada a few weeks ago. His staff grew by about 30 percent in October
election_confidence: with more than 70 people now on the campaign payroll. The new hires include communications and digital advisers
authors: as well as field workers to boost voter contact and advance staff to help set up larger and more frequent events in Iowa
article_id: the first four states to vote in the nomination contest.\nWhether Rubio can effectively build up his campaign infrastructure in those states may determine whether he can turn his natural political talents and easy appeal with GOP voters into primary victories.\n\"Everywhere I go I hear folks talking about him
column15: a Republican National Committeeman from South Carolina. \"So it's the right time to come into the state
column16: set up shop and set up more time here.\"\nWhile Rubio's advisers say they're simply executing the next phase in a carefully crafted campaign blueprint
column17: there's no doubt the team's early penny-pinching was driven in part by necessity. The senator's fundraising has been underwhelming and his money totals trailed several rivals through summer and fall
column18: including a lackluster $6 million haul in third financial reporting period of the year.\nBut buoyed by strong performances in the last two GOP debates
column19: Rubio has been attracting more high-dollar donors
column20: including billionaire investor Paul Singer and New York hedge fund manager Cliff Asness.\nWith more cash in the pipeline
column21: Rubio is expected to spend more money on travel to early voting states and on larger events aimed at putting him in front of as many voters as possible. Rubio communications director Alex Conant pointed to a 450-person event in New Hampshire last week and a similar sized event in Davenport
column23: on Wednesday as examples of the type of settings the candidate will appear at more regularly.\nRubio's more robust travel plans are welcome news to some Republicans in early voting states who have griped for months that the senator wasn't spending enough time on the ground meeting with donors and wooing important backers. While some candidates have all but taken up residency in Iowa and New Hampshire
column24: Rubio has been a more sporadic presence.\n\"He's recognizing that in order to win in New Hampshire
column25: you need to be available to voters \u00e2\u0080\u0094 not just once or twice but more often than that
column27: a prominent New Hampshire Republican. She called Rubio an \"attractive candidate\" but said she's also still considering Chris Christie and Carly Fiorina.\nRubio's backers believe the campaign's fiscal caution has already been validated by the early money woes of other candidates. Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker quickly built a large and expensive operation
column28: but was forced to withdraw from the race after just two months when his fundraising stopped covering his bills. And despite raising more than $100 million for his super PAC
column29: Florida Gov. Jeb Bush slashed payroll spending by 40 percent after campaign fundraising slowed.\nTo be sure
column30: the Rubio team's tales of cheapness have helped the campaign define the Florida senator as a scrappy underdog taking on wealthier rivals. Campaign manager Terry Sullivan has bragged about sticking Rubio on budget airline Frontier \u00e2\u0080\u0094 which he called \"a special kind of hell\" \u00e2\u0080\u0094 and touted his rule of personally approving expenses over $500.\nAt one of the campaign's Nevada offices
column31: staffers tried to do their part to live up to the less is more mantra. After noticing a pizza place next to a campaign office had free wireless internet that required a password
column32: a staffer walked over and bought two pieces of pizza and asked for the internet access code.\nBut the cost-cutting measure was short-lived. After about three weeks
column33: the pizza place caught on and asked the Rubio team to stop.\n_\nPace reported from Washington. Follow Pace at http://twitter.com/jpaceDC and Seanna Adcox at http://twitter.com/seannaadcox_ap"
column37: Marco Rubio's campaign team in South Carolina operated out of a staffer's garage
column38: plotting strategy for the first-in-the-South primary from freshly painted yard sale furniture and tiny classroom desks."
column39: "title": "Rubio's low-budget campaign looks to ramp up as voting nears"

description: "description": "\u201cNow everybody knows that they don\u2019t do that in Utah anymore
title:
right?”
View Video ›

Republican presidential candidate Ben Carson managed to find humor in a sad story from his past. 
Telling the story of his parents' divorce to the crowd at a 2010 Martin Luther King luncheon in Peoria
topics: Carson cracked a joke about his mother discovering that his father had a second wife and family. \n\"Years later she discovered he was a bigamist. Had another family. I remember telling that story at a gradation at the University of Utah. Nobody thought it was that strange.\"\n\"See that! I offended somebody
people: \" Carson said. \"Now everybody knows that they don't do that in Utah anymore
election_confidence: "title": "Watch Ben Carson's Actually Funny Joke About Polygamy"

                Obama travels to Antalya
column19: Turkey this weekend for the G20 summit where the civil war in Syria is expected to be a top agenda item. | AP Photo\n\n                        The two leaders will have \"ample\" time for conversation
column20:
a top Obama aide says. 

            By 
Eliza Collins

11/12/15 01:14 PM EST
President Barack Obama and Russian President Vladimir Putin may not have any meetings on the schedule but they may still end up talking.
“There is not a formal meeting between the president and Mr. Putin on the schedule but has often been the case at the G20 and other multilateral leaders meetings we fully expect they’ll have ample opportunity for discussion directly
column21: \u201d National Security Adviser Susan Rice said at a White House briefing Thursday.\nStory Continued Below\nObama travels to Antalya
column22:
Turkey this weekend for the G20 summit where the civil war in Syria is expected to be a top agenda item.

White House

            By 
Elana Schor
             and 
Andrew Restuccia

“The G20 meeting will come just after Secretary Kerry again convenes the key countries in Vienna along with the United Nations we’ve been working with all the key players in that configuration including the Russians
column23: \u201d Rice said. \u201cThe Russians certainly have their ideas
column25: other players have theirs and this discussion in Vienna will be an opportunity to try to see the extent to which we can forge a common way forward.\u201d \nRice said everyone will be looking for a concrete transition plan for Syria
column26: though later in the briefing she acknowledged concrete plans aren\u2019t likely to come immediately because she views it as \"a process.\"\n\u201cI think we\u2019re all very realistic for the conflict in Syria to be resolved
column28: it\u2019s going to require all the relevant players to come to a common understanding

byline: S.C.Republican presidential rivals Ted Cruz and Marco Rubio exchanged blows over illegal immigration on Thursday in what could mark the start of a protracted battle between two candidates who have been on the rise.\nMany Republican strategists believe that while Donald Trump and Ben Carson are the current front-runners in the race for the Republican nomination
description: the battle could end up being between Cruz and Rubio
title: who are getting a close look from voters because of strong debate performances.\nThat is why it was notable that Cruz
url: speaking to conservative radio talk show host Laura Ingraham
topics: cited Rubio's 2013 attempt to gain passage in Congress of comprehensive immigration reform.\nThe reform proposal was criticized by conservatives but promoted by Rubio and seven other Senators from both parties who were known as \"the gang of Gang of Eight.\" The plan would have included a pathway to citizenship for illegal immigrants who met all the requirements.\nThe effort collapsed amid partisan acrimony
people: and illegal immigration is one of the biggest flashpoints in the fight to win the Republican nomination for the presidential election in November 2016. \nCruz
election_confidence: said that he had sought to add amendments to the 2013 legislation as part of \"a concerted strategy to beat the Gang of Eight amnesty bill.\"\nRubio
date_written: \"opposed every single one of them. Every single amendment
orgs: \" Cruz said. \"The Gang of Eight voted as a gang against enforcing and securing the border.\" \nRubio was pressed by reporters on the issue in Hilton Head after participating in a presidential forum sponsored by the South Carolina Chamber of Commerce.\n\"Ted is a supporter of legalizing people that are in this country illegally
date_access: when the Senate bill was proposed
column15: he proposed giving them work permits.\"\nRubio said \"every single person\" on the Republican debate stage where the issue was debated among eight candidates in Milwaukee on Tuesday \"has supported the legalization of people who are not here legally.\"\nRubio
column17: told the South Carolina forum that any reform effort must include at the outset ensuring that the U.S. border with Mexico is sealed off from illegal immigrants because only then would Americans have confidence to move forward with granting a legal status to as many as 11 million people.\n\n (Reporting By Steve Holland)"
column20: S.C. (Reuters) - Republican presidential rivals Ted Cruz and Marco Rubio exchanged blows over illegal immigration on Thursday in what could mark the start of a protracted battle between two candidates who have been on the rise."

description: "description": "\nAlan Diaz / AP\nBen Carson says if the United States were to establish a no-fly zone in Syria and Russian planes were to enter it
title: then those planes would have to be shot down.The Republican presidential candidate made the comment to Iowa radio host Simon Conway on Wednesday after arguing that the U.S. should establish a no-fly zone over the \"Turkish-Syrian border\" to provide a safe haven for refugees.Asked whether he would enforce the no-fly zone if a Russian plane were to enter it
people: after you have given them adequate warning
org: after we have talked to Putin
authors: absolutely.\"When the host noted that shooting down a plane could provoke a response
date_access: but we can't continue backing down because in the long run
column15: that'll hurt us.\"Carson also said that he favors dialogue with the Russian president.\nw.soundcloud.com\n"

body: {"body": "The union representing postal workers is announcing its endorsement of Sen. Bernie Sanders for president\u00c2\u00a0on Thursday
byline: giving the underdog candidate a much-needed boost in his effort to topple Hillary Clinton
description: who remains far ahead in the race for union support.\nMr. Sanders\u00e2\u0080\u0099s views and record typically line up more closely with unions\u00e2\u0080\u0099 priorities
title: and the American Postal Workers Union said his years of work on their causes won members over.\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cPolitics as usual has not worked. It\u00e2\u0080\u0099s time for a political revolution
url: \u00e2\u0080\u009d union president Mark Dimondstein said in a statement
topics: echoing Mr. Sanders\u00e2\u0080\u0099s battle cry.\nHis statement appeared to dismiss concerns from some that Mr. Sanders has been a political independent for decades
people: not a Democrat. The union was unmoved by Mrs. Clinton\u00e2\u0080\u0099s recent opposition to the Trans Pacific Partnership
org: an Asian free trade agreement that unions have fought and that Mr. Sanders has long opposed.\n\u00e2\u0080\u009cWe should judge candidates not by their political party
authors: not by what we think they stand for
orgs: \u00e2\u0080\u009d Mr. Dimondstein said.\nHe also noted Mr. Sanders\u00e2\u0080\u0099s long-time efforts to fight privatization of the U.S. Postal Service
article_id: and to keep\u00c2\u00a0post offices and mail facilities open amid budget cuts.\nWhile union membership nationally has declined
date_access: the labor movement plays an important role in elections because of its ability to turn out like-minded voters to the polls.\nMrs. Clinton still has far more labor support than her rival
column15: owing to her longtime ties with union leaders
column17: and a belief among many that she is the most electable Democrat running. So far
column18: she has won endorsements of 12 national unions
column19: including a few of the largest in the nation such as the American Federation of State
column20: County and Municipal Employees and the American Federation of Teachers
column21: each of which have 1.6 million members.\nBy contrast
column22: the postal workers union has about 200
column23: 000 members. Mr. Sanders also has support of one other major national union
column28: had courted labor in general and the postal workers in particular
column30: 000 members at the union\u00e2\u0080\u0099s October conference in Las Vegas. In its announcement
column31: the union\u00e2\u0080\u0099s national executive board said it was encouraging members to participate in Sanders\u00e2\u0080\u0099s rallies and join Labor for Bernie
column32: a grassroots group of supporters from unions
column33: including some who have endorsed Mrs. Clinton and others that remain neutral.\nMore:\nOn Keystone

body: {"body": "Students were set to walk out of classrooms across the United States on Thursday to protest ballooning student loan debt for higher education and rally for tuition-free public colleges and a minimum wage hike for campus workers.\nThe demonstrations are planned just two days after thousands of fast-food workers took to the streets in a nationwide day of action pushing for a $15-an-hour minimum wage and union rights for the industry.\nEvents for Thursday's protests
description: have been planned at colleges and universities from Los Angeles to New York. Thousands of people signed up to attend on Facebook groups
title: though it remained to be seen how many would ultimately participate.\n\"Education should be free. The United States is the richest country in the world
url: yet students have to take on crippling debt in order to get a college education
topics: \" the movement's organizers said in a statement on their website.\nOrganizers are demanding tuition-free public colleges
people: a cancellation of all student debt and a $15-an-hour minimum wage for campus workers.\nThe total volume of outstanding U.S. student loan debt has more than doubled to $1.2 trillion
org: according to the U.S. Consumer Financial Protection Bureau
election_confidence: compared with less than $600 billion in 2006.\nThe bureau said there are some 8 million private and federal loan borrowers in default
date_written: while millions more are finding it difficult to keep up with repayments.\nSaddled with debt that can sometimes run into the hundreds of thousands of dollars
orgs: many college graduates have struggled to make payments amid an ailing economy and job market.\nDealing with swiftly mounting student loan debt has been a focus of candidates vying for the White House in 2016.\nDemocratic hopeful Bernie Sanders has vowed to make tuition free at public universities and colleges
article_id: and has pledged to cut interest rates for student loans. \nHis rival Hillary Clinton has said she would increase access to tuition grants
date_access: let graduates refinance loans at lower interest rates
column15: and streamline income-based repayment plans.\nFlorida U.S. Senator Marco Rubio is the most prominent Republican candidate to lay out a concrete proposal
column16: saying he would establish an income-based repayment system for federal student loans
column17: and would simplify the application process for federal aid.    \n\"This is clearly an urgent crisis
column18: but establishment politicians from both parties are failing to take action
column19: \" their statement said.\n\n (Reporting by Curtis Skinner in San Francisco; Editing by Daniel Wallis and Lisa Shumaker)"
column21: "description": "(Reuters) - Students were set to walk out of classrooms across the United States on Thursday to protest ballooning student loan debt for higher education and rally for tuition-free public colleges and a minimum wage hike for campus workers."
column22: "title": "Students across U.S. to march over debt

body: {"body": "Washington (CNN)Marco Rubio insisted he learned his lesson when he abandoned his controversial immigration bill: Congress could not tackle such an issue in a comprehensive fashion.\nBut on the campaign trail
byline: Rubio says he's open to the most controversial aspect of that plan: a pathway to citizenship for the nation's 11 million undocumented immigrants. Rubio laid out this week a list of criteria illegal immigrants would have to meet to earn citizenship -- mirroring the controversial Gang of Eight bill that he has methodically been distancing himself from after it passed the Senate in 2013.\n\"I personally am open to that
description: \" he said of a \"very long\" path to citizenship on National Public Radio.\nThe comments drew Rubio back into the fray of an issue that has dogged him with the right wing of the party since he first tried to tackle it in 2012. He has tried to project himself as a leader trying to fix a vexing issue
title: while also trying to be sensitive to the anger from the GOP base.\nBut by playing to both sides
url: Rubio has sparked criticism from the left and right and prompted sharp charges that he's choosing his position for political expediency. It's a sign that the issue is only going to heat up as he continues to ascend in the GOP race.\nSen. Jeff Sessions
people: an immigration hardliner and an aggressive opponent of the 2013 bill
org: told CNN on Thursday that GOP candidates should drop out of the race if they back a path to citizenship.\n\"Supporting citizenship for illegal immigrants should be disqualifying
election_confidence: \" Sessions said when asked about Rubio's position. \"Just like we can't have a GOP nominee who supports Obamacare
authors: we can't have a GOP nominee who supports amnesty.\"\nAlabama Rep. Mo Brooks said in an interview that Rubio's position on immigration would \"very significantly\" depress conservative voter turnout in a general election if he were the nominee.\n\"When I see what Marco has said and done
orgs: that is: Their actions and their comments are a definite concern because they undermine the ability of American families to earn enough to take care of themselves
date_access: a conservative Republican who backs Texas Sen. Ted Cruz for the nomination.\nOn Thursday
column15: Rubio tried to muddy the waters even further by telling reporters that Cruz was aligned with his position on immigration reform
column16: citing positions on H-1B visas and other matters that the Texan took during the 2013 battle. \nREAD: Why some conservatives are upset with Ted Cruz on immigration\n\"I don't think our positions are dramatically different
column17: \" Rubio said. \nBut Rubio spokesman Alex Conant said the Florida senator has made clear he  now opposes moving on a bill in a comprehensive fashion
column18: saying Washington must enact individual pieces of immigration reform -- starting with border and interior enforcement -- before debating a path to citizenship.\n\"What he has said is that the Gang of Eight bill is dead
column19: and it's not coming back and it has even less support now than it did two years ago
column20: \" Conant said Thursday. \"It's clear that the only way that the way to fix the broken immigration system is by first securing the border.\"\n\nIn April 2012
column21: a 41-year-old Rubio called a small group of reporters into his conference room to announce a rather bold step: He wanted to offer some children of undocumented immigrants the opportunity to apply for \"non-immigrant\" visas before they would be allowed to earn a more permanent legal status.\nThe plan stopped short of offering a full-blown path to citizenship
column22: as Democrats wanted. But it elevated his stature and showcased his willingness to dive in the choppy immigration waters -- just as the GOP's presidential candidate
column24: had veered right on the issue and was considering picking him as the party's vice presidential nominee.\nBut in June 2012
column25: Rubio gave up on that plan. President Barack Obama
column27: took executive action to defer deportations to certain undocumented immigrants brought to the country as children. Rubio said such executive actions undermined an effort to do anything legislatively.\n\"People are going to say to me
column28: 'Why are we going to need to do anything on this now. It has been dealt with. We can wait until after the election
column29: '\" Rubio told the Wall Street Journal at the time. \"And it is going to be hard to argue against that.\"\nAfter Romney was routed with Hispanic voters in the 2012 elections
column30: a bipartisan group of senators began negotiating behind the scenes to put together a sweeping proposal that they intended to push through Congress in 2013
column31: when Democrats controlled the Senate and occupied the White House.\nREAD: Bush on Rubio: 'I'm a better bet' against Clinton\nFor months
column32: Rubio was flirting with the group and privately negotiating details
column33: but hadn't made a formal decision about signing onto the legislative proposal until April 2013
column34: when he went on all the Sunday talk shows to aggressively defend the effort.\n\"This is not blanket amnesty
column35: \" Rubio said at the time.\nAs the measure headed to the Senate floor
column36: Rubio sided with fellow negotiators to defeat any controversial amendments aimed at changing the structure of the plan. He voted against an amendment by Sen. John Thune
column38: to require the completion of 700 miles of\nfencing at the border before allowing the pathway to citizenship plan to move forward. And he opposed a plan by Sen. David Vitter
column40: requiring that the country's biometric entry-exit system of tracking people crossing the border is fully implemented before giving legal status to undocumented immigrants.\nMoments before the bill's passage
column43: said: \"Generations of unfulfilled dreams will finally come to pass
column44: \" adding: \"That's why I support this reform.\"\n\nBut after the bill's passage
column45: Rubio began to speak much less frequently about the matter. Even though the rest of the Gang of Eight was still meeting regularly to strategize over how to ratchet up pressure on House Republicans to take up the bill
column47: saying that the issue was now in the hands of the GOP-led House
column48: which never called the plan up for a vote.\nBy taking that approach
column49: Rubio began to make amends with many conservatives who were furious at his position
column50: but he angered fellow proponents of immigration reform who believed he was caving to political pressure.\nIn an interview with CNN last week
column53: one of the co-authors of the bill
